awd_titl_txt: The Moving Mountains Summit: Collaboratively Redefining the Future of Mountain Environments and Society
awd_abstract_narration:
Mountain environments provide critical resources – such as clean water, forests, food, and medicines – to over half of the world’s population.  Mountain systems are also facing some of the most extreme effects of climate change.  This project will support the Moving Mountains Summit, an event that will advance scientific and practical knowledge regarding the future trajectories of mountain environments and human communities. The Summit’s participants will take part in workshops to address key issues including food security, livelihoods, tourism, and energy and the connections among them. Participants will explore how people, policy, and science can team up to build resilience in the face of climate change, and catalyze changes toward a sustainable, equitable and secure future for mountain environments and societies. Indigenous peoples and knowledge will play a prominent role in the Summit and in identifying pathways toward the future. The Summit will thus make a substantive intellectual contribution to synergies among Indigenous knowledge, Western science, and other knowledge systems. It will also expand the process for how we do science and increase public participation in the scientific process.  

The Moving Mountains Summit will leverage the synergistic power of science, local and Indigenous knowledge, business, policy and advocacy to build and strengthen enduring links  between key players in mountains and address mountain environmental and community  sustainability in the post-COVID world while facing accelerating effects of climate change.   
The Summit will be a hybrid meeting with the in-person portion taking place at the Rocky Mountain Institute’s Innovation Center in Basalt, Colorado, USA. For those who cannot attend the Colorado meeting, participants in different locations around the world can convene in-person at ‘regional meet-up mountain-hubs’ such as Kathmandu, Nepal and Huaraz, Peru. A fully supported online-only option will be available for those who are not able or choose not to travel. Summit outcomes will include: a clearly articulated and shared vision with metrics to assess progress; a theory of change and related “road map”; new partnerships across diverse actors and sectors; media products; peer-reviewed publications; a Summit Declaration of Values; and commitments to an Action Plan towards sustainable mountain futures. The Summit will help build collaborations among mountain researchers, practitioners, entrepreneurs, and stakeholders by establishing the Mountain Sentinels network as a boundary spanning organization for meaningful and broad engagement among mountain Indigenous and western scientists and stakeholders, globally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Moving Mountains Summit hosted 36 in-person attendees from September 23-25, 2022 in Basalt, Colorado at the Rocky Mountain Institute?s Innovation Center, a LEED Platinum designated building.  The hybrid Summit also hosted 40 online participants from different mountain regions worldwide. Overall, there were 11 different countries represented from five different continents. Two Indigenous facilitators (including one indigenous youth who was training to undertake facilitation work) and one western facilitator helped to co-develop and co-lead several Summit activities, including the River of Life, a multi-part participatory group activity to explore mountain challenges and to identify possible shared approaches to address these challenges. 

The Summit bridged the end of the NSF RCN-funded Mountain Sentinels Collaborative Network and the launch of the newly funded NSF AccelNet Mountain Sentinels Alliance. The Summit immediately preceded the UN Mountain Partnerships Meeting, in Aspen, Colorado, which celebrated the UN?s official designation of 2022 as the as the ?International Year of Sustainable Mountain Development? and allowed Summit participants to contribute two sessions to the UN event: one focused on braiding knowledge systems and the other focused on higher education?s contribution to sustainable mountain development.

The goals of the Moving Mountains Summit were to build relationships and connections with other mountain networks; engage in cultural learning to increase knowledge of local and Indigenous values to strengthen mountain science; and to design an action plan with partnering communities and networks for mountain sustainability.

Outcomes from the Summit include a draft Declaration of Core Values as a foundational document. Ideas presented in this document provide a framework for building relationships with collaborators, partners, participants, and all other groups with whom Mountain Sentinels interacts. Ideas in this document will inform co-development of future events and research, and act as a guiding operational document for the Alliance. The Summit also resulted in identification of five key research-action areas:

a)     Ethical space for research and data governance

b)    Climate action & nature-based solutions

c)     Centering Indigenous and local communities for sustainable mountain futures

d)    Youth involvement and intergenerational exchange

e)     Sustainable livelihoods

Other products from the Summit include podcasts, publications, a news article, professional graphic recordings, a blog post, and shared learning resources. The Summit also provided an opportunity for training and exchange for Indigenous and non-Indigenous early career Fellows, undergraduate, and graduate student participants.  

The Summit enabled globally-representative teams of mountain scientists and stakeholders to explore approaches to transdisciplinary research, including the AccelNet goals of acceleration of the process of scientific discovery and preparing the next generation of U.S. researchers for multiteam international collaborations. Impacts include increasing public engagement with science and technology, pathways toward increased partnerships between academia, industry, and community stakeholders, and collaboration pathways that could assist with development of a diverse STEM workforce. 

The approach to science and addressing complex mountain problems - with diverse peoples and knowledge systems - requires bridging boundaries across disciplines and more.  The Core Values developed at the Summit can be applied across disciplines.  The working groups also span disciplinary boundaries and are a model for how to do this. The Summit provided opportunity for deep thought about how different groups interact and how to contribute to a safe, equitable space to prepare for these interactions.

Many sessions of the Summit, particularly those sessions led by the Indigenous facilitation team, involved group work to cooperatively create interpretative art using art and craft supplies. This approach was designed to facilitate sharing of ideas in a more culturally inclusive, non-linear, and nonverbal way. Participants responded that sharing ideas in this format led to a deeper understanding of fellow participants and their perspectives. 

The engagement of a graphic facilitator and the ability to capture and display main points in a visual context offered participants who are visual learners and those who speak English as a second language or are monolingual non-English speakers an opportunity to engage with ideas presented at the Summit on their own time and their own terms.

The Summit brought together so many different ways of knowing that it both highlighted the power of collective engagement and the challenges in equitably working with diverse knowledge systems. Many summit activities sparked trust and understanding among participants, and laid the foundation for future relationships.  The challenges and successes of the Summit emphasize the importance of cross-cultural collaboration across society, within and beyond science and technology.
